DOS Header.title: DOS Header (MZ Header)
DOS Header.description: The DOS header is the first structure in every PE file. It was originally designed for DOS compatibility but now serves as a legacy header that points to the actual PE header. The magic number 'MZ' (0x5A4D) identifies this as a valid executable file.
DOS Header.purpose: Provides backward compatibility and contains the offset to the PE header
DOS Header.security_notes: Legacy header - no direct security implications, but must be present for valid PE files

PE Header.title: PE Header (File Header)
PE Header.description: The PE header contains essential information about the file format, including the target machine type, number of sections, and characteristics. It follows the DOS header and contains the core PE format information.
PE Header.purpose: Define the basic PE file structure and characteristics
PE Header.security_notes: Critical for file validation - check Machine field for unexpected architectures and Characteristics for suspicious flags

Optional Header.title: Optional Header
Optional Header.description: The optional header contains detailed information about the executable, including entry point, image base, section alignment, and subsystem information. It's essential for the Windows loader to properly load and execute the file.
Optional Header.purpose: Provide detailed loading and execution information for the Windows loader
Optional Header.security_notes: Critical security fields include EntryPoint, ImageBase, and DllCharacteristics. Unusual values may indicate malicious modifications.

Sections.title: PE Sections
Sections.description: Sections contain the actual code, data, and resources of the executable. Each section has specific characteristics and permissions that determine how it's loaded into memory and what operations are allowed.
Sections.purpose: Organize executable content into logical, loadable segments with specific permissions
Sections.security_notes: Critical for security analysis - check section characteristics for suspicious permissions, look for hidden sections, and verify section alignment

Data Directories.title: Data Directories
Data Directories.description: Data directories point to important structures within the file, such as import/export tables, resources, and security information. They provide the loader with locations of critical data needed for execution.
Data Directories.purpose: Locate important data structures for loading and execution
Data Directories.security_notes: Import/Export directories are critical for security analysis. Check for suspicious imports, unexpected exports, and verify directory integrity

e_magic.title: Magic Number (e_magic)
e_magic.description: This 16-bit value must be 0x5A4D ('MZ' in ASCII). It's the signature that identifies this file as a valid DOS executable. The 'MZ' stands for Mark Zbikowski, one of the original DOS developers.
e_magic.security_notes: Critical validation field - any other value indicates file corruption or manipulation. Malware authors sometimes try to modify this to bypass basic file type detection.

e_cblp.title: Bytes on Last Page (e_cblp)
e_cblp.description: The number of bytes on the last page of the file. This field is used to determine the exact size of the file.
e_cblp.purpose: Calculate exact file size for DOS compatibility
e_cblp.security_notes: Unusual values might indicate file manipulation or padding.

e_cp.title: Pages in File (e_cp)
e_cp.description: The number of pages in the file. In DOS, files were organized in 512-byte pages.
e_cp.security_notes: Legacy field with minimal security implications.

e_crlc.title: Relocations (e_crlc)
e_crlc.description: The number of relocation entries in the file. These are used to adjust addresses when the file cannot be loaded at its preferred base address.
e_crlc.purpose: Handle address space conflicts in DOS
e_crlc.security_notes: High numbers might indicate complex relocations or manipulation.

e_cparhdr.title: Size of Header (e_cparhdr)
e_cparhdr.description: The size of the header in paragraphs (16-byte units). This includes the DOS header and any additional header information.
e_cparhdr.security_notes: Unusual header sizes might indicate header manipulation.

e_minalloc.title: Minimum Allocation (e_minalloc)
e_minalloc.description: The minimum number of paragraphs of memory that the program needs to run.
e_minalloc.security_notes: Very high values might indicate memory allocation attacks.

e_maxalloc.title: Maximum Allocation (e_maxalloc)
e_maxalloc.description: The maximum number of paragraphs of memory that the program can use.
e_maxalloc.security_notes: Unusually high values might indicate memory exhaustion attacks.

e_ss.title: Initial SS (e_ss)
e_ss.description: The initial value of the SS register (stack segment) when the program starts.
e_ss.security_notes: Unusual stack locations might indicate stack manipulation.

e_sp.title: Initial SP (e_sp)
e_sp.description: The initial value of the SP register (stack pointer) when the program starts.
e_sp.security_notes: Unusual stack pointers might indicate stack overflow attempts.

e_csum.title: Checksum (e_csum)
e_csum.description: A checksum value for the file. This field is often set to 0 in modern PE files.
e_csum.security_notes: Non-zero checksums should be validated. Zero is normal for modern files.

e_ip.title: Initial IP (e_ip)
e_ip.description: The initial value of the IP register (instruction pointer) when the program starts.
e_ip.security_notes: Unusual instruction pointers might indicate code injection.

e_cs.title: Initial CS (e_cs)
e_cs.description: The initial value of the CS register (code segment) when the program starts.
e_cs.security_notes: Unusual code segments might indicate segment manipulation.

e_lfarlc.title: File Address of Relocation Table (e_lfarlc)
e_lfarlc.description: The file address of the relocation table. This points to the relocation entries.
e_lfarlc.security_notes: Unusual relocation table locations might indicate manipulation.

e_ovno.title: Overlay Number (e_ovno)
e_ovno.description: The overlay number. This field is typically 0 for the main program.
e_ovno.security_notes: Non-zero values might indicate overlay-based malware.

e_lfanew.title: PE Header Offset (e_lfanew)
e_lfanew.description: This 32-bit value contains the file offset to the PE header. It tells the loader where to find the actual Portable Executable header within the file. This offset is typically 0x80 (128 bytes) or larger.
e_lfanew.purpose: Locate the PE header for modern Windows execution
e_lfanew.calculation: File offset from beginning of file to PE signature
e_lfanew.security_notes: Suspicious if offset is very large (>0x1000) - could indicate file padding to hide malicious content. Also check if offset points to valid PE signature.

Signature.title: PE Signature
Signature.description: The PE signature that identifies this as a valid Portable Executable file. Must be 0x00004550 ('PE\0\0' in ASCII).
Signature.security_notes: Critical validation field - any other value indicates file corruption or manipulation.

Machine.title: Machine Type
Machine.description: Specifies the target CPU architecture for this executable. Common values include: 0x014C (Intel 386), 0x8664 (AMD64), 0x01C0 (ARM), 0xAA64 (ARM64).
Machine.purpose: Ensure the executable runs on compatible hardware
Machine.security_notes: Check for architecture mismatch - running 64-bit malware on 32-bit system or vice versa. Some malware uses multiple architectures in single file.

NumberOfSections.title: Number of Sections
NumberOfSections.description: Indicates how many sections are defined in the section table. Each section represents a logical division of the executable (code, data, resources, etc.). Typical executables have 3-10 sections.
NumberOfSections.purpose: Define the file's logical structure and memory layout
NumberOfSections.security_notes: Suspicious if very few sections (<3) or too many (>15). Few sections might indicate packed/obfuscated code. Many sections could indicate code injection or complex malware.

TimeDateStamp.title: Time/Date Stamp
TimeDateStamp.description: Contains the timestamp when the executable was created or last modified. This is stored as seconds since January 1, 1970 (Unix epoch).
TimeDateStamp.security_notes: Check for suspicious timestamps: future dates, very old dates, or dates matching known malware campaigns. Timestamp manipulation is common in malware.

PointerToSymbolTable.title: Pointer to Symbol Table
PointerToSymbolTable.description: Points to the COFF symbol table. This is typically 0 in modern PE files as symbol information is usually stored in separate PDB files.
PointerToSymbolTable.security_notes: Non-zero values in release builds might indicate debug information left behind or manipulation.

NumberOfSymbols.title: Number of Symbols
NumberOfSymbols.description: The number of symbols in the COFF symbol table. This is typically 0 in modern PE files.
NumberOfSymbols.security_notes: Non-zero values in release builds might indicate debug information left behind or manipulation.

SizeOfOptionalHeader.title: Size of Optional Header
SizeOfOptionalHeader.description: The size of the optional header in bytes. This field indicates how much optional header data follows the PE header.
SizeOfOptionalHeader.security_notes: Unusual sizes might indicate header manipulation or corruption.

Characteristics.title: File Characteristics
Characteristics.description: A set of flags that describe the executable's properties: 0x0002 (Executable), 0x2000 (DLL), 0x0001 (Relocation info stripped), 0x0100 (32-bit word machine).
Characteristics.security_notes: DLL characteristics in EXE files are suspicious. Stripped relocation info can indicate packed malware. Check for unusual combinations of flags.

Magic.title: Magic Number
Magic.description: Identifies the type of optional header: 0x010B (PE32), 0x020B (PE32+).
Magic.security_notes: Must match file architecture. Mismatch could indicate file corruption or manipulation. Some malware tries to confuse analysis tools.

MajorLinkerVersion.title: Major Linker Version
MajorLinkerVersion.description: The major version of the linker that created this executable.
MajorLinkerVersion.security_notes: Very old or very new linker versions might indicate suspicious compilation or manipulation.

MinorLinkerVersion.title: Minor Linker Version
MinorLinkerVersion.description: The minor version of the linker that created this executable.
MinorLinkerVersion.security_notes: Very old or very new linker versions might indicate suspicious compilation or manipulation.

SizeOfCode.title: Size of Code
SizeOfCode.description: The size of the code section in bytes. This represents the total size of all code sections combined.
SizeOfCode.security_notes: Suspicious if very large or very small compared to file size. Could indicate code injection or obfuscation.

SizeOfInitializedData.title: Size of Initialized Data
SizeOfInitializedData.description: The size of the initialized data section in bytes. This includes all data sections that contain initialized values.
SizeOfInitializedData.security_notes: Unusual sizes might indicate data injection or manipulation.

SizeOfUninitializedData.title: Size of Uninitialized Data
SizeOfUninitializedData.description: The size of the uninitialized data section (BSS) in bytes. This section is filled with zeros at load time.
SizeOfUninitializedData.security_notes: Large BSS sections might indicate malware trying to allocate memory for unpacking or code injection.

AddressOfEntryPoint.title: Address of Entry Point
AddressOfEntryPoint.description: The relative virtual address (RVA) where execution begins when the program starts. This points to the first instruction that will be executed.
AddressOfEntryPoint.purpose: Define the starting point of program execution
AddressOfEntryPoint.security_notes: CRITICAL SECURITY FIELD! Suspicious if: 1) Points to data section (not code), 2) Very low address (<0x1000), 3) Points to last section, 4) Points to overlay. These often indicate packed malware or code injection.

BaseOfCode.title: Base of Code
BaseOfCode.description: The RVA of the beginning of the code section when loaded into memory.
BaseOfCode.security_notes: Unusual base addresses might indicate code injection or manipulation.

BaseOfData.title: Base of Data
BaseOfData.description: The RVA of the beginning of the data section when loaded into memory. This field is only present in PE32 files.
BaseOfData.security_notes: Unusual base addresses might indicate data injection or manipulation.

ImageBase.title: Image Base
ImageBase.description: The preferred base address in memory where the executable should be loaded. The default is 0x00400000 for 32-bit and 0x0000000140000000 for 64-bit executables.
ImageBase.purpose: Optimize memory layout and reduce relocation overhead
ImageBase.security_notes: Endereços base incomuns podem indicar malware tentando evitar detecção ou conflito com outros processos. Verifique valores não padrão.

SectionAlignment.title: Section Alignment
SectionAlignment.description: The alignment of sections in memory. Sections are aligned to this boundary when loaded into memory. Common values are 0x1000 (4KB) for 32-bit and 0x2000 (8KB) for 64-bit.
SectionAlignment.security_notes: Unusual alignment values might indicate manipulation or non-standard compilation.

FileAlignment.title: File Alignment
FileAlignment.description: The alignment of sections in the file. Raw data is aligned to this boundary on disk. Common values are 0x200 (512 bytes) or 0x1000 (4KB).
FileAlignment.security_notes: Unusual file alignment might indicate manipulation or non-standard compilation.

MajorOperatingSystemVersion.title: Major Operating System Version
MajorOperatingSystemVersion.description: The major version number of the operating system required to run this executable.
MajorOperatingSystemVersion.security_notes: Unusual OS version requirements might indicate targeted malware or compatibility issues.

MinorOperatingSystemVersion.title: Minor Operating System Version
MinorOperatingSystemVersion.description: The minor version number of the operating system required to run this executable.
MinorOperatingSystemVersion.security_notes: Unusual OS version requirements might indicate targeted malware or compatibility issues.

MajorImageVersion.title: Major Image Version
MajorImageVersion.description: The major version number of the image itself. This is typically set by the developer.
MajorImageVersion.security_notes: Unusual version numbers might indicate manipulation or fake versioning.

MinorImageVersion.title: Minor Image Version
MinorImageVersion.description: The minor version number of the image itself. This is typically set by the developer.
MinorImageVersion.security_notes: Unusual version numbers might indicate manipulation or fake versioning.

MajorSubsystemVersion.title: Major Subsystem Version
MajorSubsystemVersion.description: The major version number of the subsystem required to run this executable.
MajorSubsystemVersion.security_notes: Unusual subsystem version requirements might indicate compatibility issues or manipulation.

MinorSubsystemVersion.title: Minor Subsystem Version
MinorSubsystemVersion.description: The minor version number of the subsystem required to run this executable.
MinorSubsystemVersion.security_notes: Unusual subsystem version requirements might indicate compatibility issues or manipulation.

Win32VersionValue.title: Win32 Version Value
Win32VersionValue.description: Reserved field that should be 0. This field is not used by the Windows loader.
Win32VersionValue.security_notes: Non-zero values might indicate file corruption or non-standard PE format.

SizeOfImage.title: Size of Image
SizeOfImage.description: The total size of the image when loaded into memory, including all headers and sections.
SizeOfImage.security_notes: Unusual image sizes might indicate code injection or manipulation.

SizeOfHeaders.title: Size of Headers
SizeOfHeaders.description: The combined size of the DOS stub, PE header, and section headers.
SizeOfHeaders.security_notes: Unusual header sizes might indicate header manipulation or corruption.

CheckSum.title: CheckSum
CheckSum.description: A checksum value for the image. This field is used for integrity verification.
CheckSum.security_notes: Non-zero checksums should be validated. Zero is normal for many files.

Subsystem.title: Subsystem
Subsystem.description: Specifies the Windows subsystem that will run this executable: 2 (Windows GUI), 3 (Windows CUI), 1 (Native), 5 (OS/2 CUI).
Subsystem.purpose: Determine how Windows should handle the application
Subsystem.security_notes: Native subsystem (1) in user-mode executables is suspicious - indicates kernel-mode code running in user space. Could be rootkit or privilege escalation attempt.

DllCharacteristics.title: DLL Characteristics
DllCharacteristics.description: Flags that describe DLL-specific properties: 0x0001 (High entropy VA), 0x0002 (Dynamic base), 0x0004 (Force integrity), 0x0008 (NX compatible), 0x0010 (Isolation aware), 0x0020 (No SEH), 0x0040 (Do not bind), 0x0080 (App container), 0x0100 (WDM driver), 0x2000 (Terminal server aware).
DllCharacteristics.purpose: Define DLL behavior and security features
DllCharacteristics.security_notes: Missing security flags (NX compatible, Force integrity) might indicate vulnerable code. High entropy VA and Dynamic base help prevent ASLR bypasses.

SizeOfStackReserve.title: Size of Stack Reserve
SizeOfStackReserve.description: The size of the stack to reserve in virtual memory. This is the maximum stack size the process can use.
SizeOfStackReserve.security_notes: Very large stack reserves might indicate stack overflow attacks or memory exhaustion attempts.

SizeOfStackCommit.title: Size of Stack Commit
SizeOfStackCommit.description: The size of the stack to commit in virtual memory. This is the initial stack size that is actually allocated.
SizeOfStackCommit.security_notes: Unusual stack commit sizes might indicate manipulation or optimization attempts.

SizeOfHeapReserve.title: Size of Heap Reserve
SizeOfHeapReserve.description: The size of the local heap to reserve in virtual memory. This is the maximum heap size the process can use.
SizeOfHeapReserve.security_notes: Very large heap reserves might indicate memory exhaustion attacks or manipulation.

SizeOfHeapCommit.title: Size of Heap Commit
SizeOfHeapCommit.description: The size of the local heap to commit in virtual memory. This is the initial heap size that is actually allocated.
SizeOfHeapCommit.security_notes: Unusual heap commit sizes might indicate manipulation or optimization attempts.

LoaderFlags.title: Loader Flags
LoaderFlags.description: Flags that control the loader behavior: 0x0001 (Break on load), 0x0002 (Debug on load), 0x0004 (Default break on load), 0x0008 (Default debug on load), 0x0010 (Incremental link), 0x0020 (Suppress incremental link), 0x0040 (Safe SEH handler), 0x0080 (Guard CF), 0x0100 (Terminal server aware).
LoaderFlags.security_notes: Debug flags enabled in release builds are suspicious. Missing security flags might indicate vulnerable code.

NumberOfRvaAndSizes.title: Number of RVA and Sizes
NumberOfRvaAndSizes.description: The number of data directory entries that follow. This should always be 16 for standard PE files.
NumberOfRvaAndSizes.purpose: Define the number of data directories
NumberOfRvaAndSizes.security_notes: Values other than 16 might indicate file corruption or non-standard PE format.

Name.title: Section Name
Name.description: An 8-character name that identifies the section. Common names include .text (code), .data (data), .rdata (read-only data), .idata (imports), .edata (exports), .rsrc (resources), .reloc (relocations).
Name.security_notes: Suspicious section names: UPX0/UPX1 (packed), .aspack, .vmp0 (VMProtect), .themida. Unusual names might indicate obfuscation or malware.

SectionName.title: Section Name
SectionName.description: An 8-character name that identifies the section. Common names include .text (code), .data (data), .rdata (read-only data), .idata (imports), .edata (exports), .rsrc (resources), .reloc (relocations).
SectionName.security_notes: Suspicious section names: UPX0/UPX1 (packed), .aspack, .vmp0 (VMProtect), .themida. Unusual names might indicate obfuscation or malware.

VirtualSize.title: Virtual Size
VirtualSize.description: The size of the section when loaded into memory. This may be different from the raw data size due to alignment requirements and padding.
VirtualSize.security_notes: Suspicious if virtual size >> raw size - could indicate unpacking or code injection. Very large virtual sizes might be malware trying to allocate excessive memory.

VirtualAddress.title: Virtual Address
VirtualAddress.description: The relative virtual address (RVA) where this section will be loaded in memory. This is relative to the image base address.
VirtualAddress.purpose: Define memory layout and section positioning
VirtualAddress.security_notes: Suspicious if virtual address is very low (<0x1000) or overlaps with other sections. Could indicate code injection or section manipulation.

SizeOfRawData.title: Size of Raw Data
SizeOfRawData.description: The actual size of the section data stored in the file. This represents the number of bytes that will be read from disk.
SizeOfRawData.note: Must be aligned to file alignment boundary
SizeOfRawData.security_notes: Suspicious if raw size is 0 but virtual size > 0 - indicates uninitialized data section that could be used for code injection. Very large raw sizes might indicate embedded malicious content.

PointerToRawData.title: Pointer to Raw Data
PointerToRawData.description: The file offset where the section's raw data begins. This tells the loader where to read the section data from disk.
PointerToRawData.purpose: Locate section data within the file
PointerToRawData.format: File offset from beginning of file
PointerToRawData.security_notes: Check for suspicious offsets pointing to overlay or very large values. Could indicate hidden malicious content or file manipulation.

PointerToRelocations.title: Pointer to Relocations
PointerToRelocations.description: Pointer to the relocation table for this section. This is typically 0 in modern PE files.
PointerToRelocations.security_notes: Non-zero values might indicate complex relocations or manipulation.

PointerToLinenumbers.title: Pointer to Line Numbers
PointerToLinenumbers.description: Pointer to the line number table for this section. This is typically 0 in release builds.
PointerToLinenumbers.security_notes: Non-zero values in release builds might indicate debug information left behind or manipulation.

NumberOfRelocations.title: Number of Relocations
NumberOfRelocations.description: The number of relocation entries for this section. Relocations are needed when the section cannot be loaded at its preferred virtual address.
NumberOfRelocations.note: Usually 0 for most sections in modern executables
NumberOfRelocations.security_notes: High number of relocations in unusual sections might indicate code injection or manipulation. Check if relocations point to suspicious addresses.

NumberOfLinenumbers.title: Number of Line Numbers
NumberOfLinenumbers.description: The number of line number entries for this section. These are used for debugging to map machine code back to source code.
NumberOfLinenumbers.security_notes: Line numbers in suspicious sections might help trace malware origin. Missing line numbers in code sections could indicate obfuscation.

SectionCharacteristics.title: Section Characteristics
SectionCharacteristics.description: Flags that define the section's properties and permissions. Common flags: 0x20 (contains code), 0x40 (contains initialized data), 0x80 (contains uninitialized data), 0x20000000 (executable), 0x80000000 (readable), 0x40000000 (writable).
SectionCharacteristics.security_notes: CRITICAL: Executable data sections (0x40 + 0x20000000) are highly suspicious - indicates code injection. Writable code sections (0x20 + 0x40000000) suggest self-modifying code or malware.

VirtualAddress_DataDir.title: Data Directory RVA
VirtualAddress_DataDir.description: The relative virtual address (RVA) of the data directory entry.
VirtualAddress_DataDir.purpose: Locate data directory content in memory
VirtualAddress_DataDir.security_notes: Verify that RVA points to valid section content, not to overlay or invalid memory regions.

Size_DataDir.title: Data Directory Size
Size_DataDir.description: The size of the data directory entry in bytes.
Size_DataDir.security_notes: Unusual sizes might indicate data injection or manipulation.

OriginalFirstThunk.title: Original First Thunk
OriginalFirstThunk.description: RVA to the original thunk table containing function names and ordinals.
OriginalFirstThunk.security_notes: Manipulation of this field can hide imported functions or redirect imports.

TimeDateStamp_Import.title: Import Time/Date Stamp
TimeDateStamp_Import.description: Timestamp when the import was bound. 0 indicates not bound, -1 indicates bound.
TimeDateStamp_Import.security_notes: Unusual timestamps might indicate import manipulation or binding issues.

ForwarderChain.title: Forwarder Chain
ForwarderChain.description: Index into the forwarder chain. -1 if no forwarders.
ForwarderChain.security_notes: Complex forwarder chains might indicate obfuscation or redirection.

Name_Import.title: Import DLL Name
Name_Import.description: RVA to the name of the DLL being imported from.
Name_Import.security_notes: Check for suspicious DLL names or imports from non-standard locations.

FirstThunk.title: First Thunk
FirstThunk.description: RVA to the import address table (IAT) that will be filled with function addresses.
FirstThunk.security_notes: IAT manipulation is common in malware to hide imported functions.

Characteristics_Export.title: Export Characteristics
Characteristics_Export.security_notes: Non-zero values might indicate corruption or manipulation.

TimeDateStamp_Export.title: Export Time/Date Stamp
TimeDateStamp_Export.description: Timestamp when the export table was created.
TimeDateStamp_Export.security_notes: Unusual timestamps might indicate manipulation or fake exports.

MajorVersion_Export.title: Export Major Version
MajorVersion_Export.description: Major version number of the export table.
MajorVersion_Export.security_notes: Unusual version numbers might indicate manipulation.

MinorVersion_Export.title: Export Minor Version
MinorVersion_Export.description: Minor version number of the export table.
MinorVersion_Export.security_notes: Unusual version numbers might indicate manipulation.

Name_Export.title: Export Module Name
Name_Export.description: RVA to the name of the module that contains the exports.
Name_Export.security_notes: Verify module name matches expected values.

OrdinalBase.title: Ordinal Base
OrdinalBase.security_notes: Unusual ordinal bases might indicate manipulation.

NumberOfFunctions.title: Number of Functions
NumberOfFunctions.security_notes: Unusually large numbers might indicate code injection or fake exports.

NumberOfNames.title: Number of Names
NumberOfNames.description: Number of exported functions with names.
NumberOfNames.security_notes: Should match or be less than NumberOfFunctions.

AddressOfFunctions.title: Address of Functions
AddressOfFunctions.description: RVA to the array of function addresses.
AddressOfFunctions.security_notes: Verify addresses point to valid code sections.

AddressOfNames.title: Address of Names
AddressOfNames.description: RVA to the array of function name pointers.
AddressOfNames.security_notes: Verify names are valid and not suspicious.

AddressOfNameOrdinals.title: Address of Name Ordinals
AddressOfNameOrdinals.description: RVA to the array of ordinal numbers.
AddressOfNameOrdinals.security_notes: Verify ordinals are within valid range.

suspicious_patterns: Zero raw size with non-zero virtual size
malware_techniques: Overlay attacks via PE header manipulation
